title: Winestein Uncorked: sneak peak at WA's best wines
text:
Some of the wines that won gold at the Qantas Wine Show of WA.
The biggest and best wine tasting hits town this Sunday and is a must for any fan of West Australian wine.
We know WA produces the highest proportion of premium wine than anywhere else in Australia , and the Top 50 Tasting at Print Hall is the best place to try most of them.
We reveal 15 of the top 50 below - scroll down to see what made the list 
Our wine industry will salute WA's best drops when they are revealed at the Qantas Wine Show Awards Dinner on October 30, but you can taste the medal winners from that show, all in the one place.
Advertisement Wine enthusiasts can compare and discuss wines, while enjoying canapés from the renowned Print Hall kitchen.
Judges had their work cut out this year, with more than 1000 wines submitted for entry on the back of yet another top vintage in the west, with cabernet, riesling and chardonnay classes particularly strong.
It's not possible for every judge to rate every wine, so they are split into three groups - with each panel (a panel leader, two judges and two associate judges) scoring about 350 wines over three days.
The state's premier wine show is now in its 38th year and judges the best of WA-grown wines. Originally featuring only six classes in 1978, the show now includes 43 classes, including the prestigious best wine of show, a sign of the growth of premium wine in the west.
After a class is judged, the panel compares scores and any wine pointed 18.5 or above (gold medal worthy) is re-poured for another tasting and dissection before chief judge Jane Faulkner and each panel decide which deserve gold.
Click here to WIN a double pass to the Top 50 tasting 
The whole judging process is neither easy nor pleasant; swirling, sniffing and spitting 60 cabernets at 8am may sound enticing but teeth go black within hours (and shouldn't be brushed until the next morning) and constant concentration is required all day.
Luckily experience is always on hand - panel leaders and judges include Gourmet Traveller Winemaker of the Year Virginia Willcock from Vasse Felix, Hong Kong wine guru Eddie McDougall and renowned local riesling guru Rob Diletti.
Although winners won't be announced until the awards night next Friday, we can reveal some gold-medal winners below that you can try at the top 50 tasting, while we review five other gold-medal wines from the show further down.
10 gold-medal winners from the show: 
1. 2015 Larry Cherubino Ad Hoc Riesling
2. 2015 Sandalford Margaret River Classic Dry White
3. 2014 Forest Hill Vineyard Block 1 Riesling
4. 2014 Talisman Gabrielle Chardonnay
5. 2014 Vasse Felix Heytesbury Chardonnay
6. 2014 Singlefile Family Reserve Chardonnay
7. 2013 Voyager Estate Chardonnay
8. 2013 Devil's Lair Ninth Chamber Chardonnay
9. 2013 Alkoomi Black Label Shiraz Viognier
10. 2015 Xanadu Next of Kin SBS
Winestein Uncorked – 5 gold-medal winners from the show 
2014 Sandalford Margaret River Shiraz
$20, 15%, 94pts 
Sandalford is an institution in the west and arguably making wines better than ever, as evidenced by several gold medals at the WA Wine Show for their $20 range of wines. This wine highlights the quality of Margaret River shiraz – a sweet-fruit wine with velvet tannins and a long, gentle finish, the 2% splash of viognier adding vanilla and cinnamon spice. What a bargain.
2012 Xanadu Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon
$85, 14.5pts, 97pts 
Sourced from the famed Wilyabrup sub-region of Margaret River, this houses 5% each of petit verdot and malbec – a true Bordeaux blend minus the merlot. There's a cascade of dark berry flavours on the palate, enhanced by top-quality firm tannins and fine oak.
2015 Kerrigan + Berry Riesling
$30, 11.5%, 95pts 
Made from the historic Langton vineyard in Mt Barker. Impressive seamless structure, bright acidity and lingering complex flavours that lean towards citrus and spice – what's not to love?
2014 Rockcliffe Single Site Pinot Noir
$40, 14%, 94pts 
There's a Japanese twist on the nose, with satsuma, caramel and soy. Has quite the structure and poise, with sweet cherry and plum prancing elegantly on the palate. Will really puff its chest out in a few years.
2012 Vasse Felix Cabernet Sauvignon
$42, 14.5%, 95pts 
From Gourmet Traveller Winemaker of the Year Virginia Willcock comes another solid cabernet from Margaret River's first winery. It's pristine in every way, extremely well balanced and ripe upfront fruit that slowly evolves on the palate long after it's gone down.
The Top 50 Tasting
Date:  Sunday 25 October
Time:  4pm-7pm
Price:  $55pp
Location:  Print Hall, St Georges Tce, Perth
Tickets:   www.wineshowwa.com.au
